translated: For example, the section on the primary life-force, beginning with This life-force is born from the Self, is stronger than the position of the six questions, which proves that the entire Upanishad is about God.

original: ata evātrādhikaraṇe ṣaṭpraśnoktaprāṇavyavasthāpakatvādīnāṃ mukhyaprāṇaliṅgatvamupetya śrutyā bādha uktaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva atra adhikaraṇe ṣaṭpraśna ukta prāṇa vyavasthāpaka tva ādīnām mukhya prāṇa liṅga tvam upetya śrutyā bādhaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Therefore, in this section, the primary life-force is considered to be the indicator, and its contradiction by scripture is stated.

original: samākhyāpekṣayā prabalaṃ sthānam /🔽yathā annamayādiśabdānāṃ kośaparatvasādhakāt 'annamayaprāṇamayamanomayavijñānamayānandamayā me śudhyantām' / yājñikī / /
analyzed: samākhyā apekṣayā prabalam sthānam  yathā anna maya ādi śabdānām kośa para tva sādhakāt anna maya prāṇa maya manaḥ maya vijñāna maya ānanda mayāḥ me śudhyantām yājñikī
translated: Position is stronger than name.

original: iti nārāyaṇānuvākasamākhyāyāḥ prabalaṃ teṣāṃ viṣṇutvasādhakaṃ brahmaparānekaprakaraṇasandarbharūpaṃ sthānam /
analyzed: iti nārāyaṇa anuvāka samākhyāyāḥ prabalam teṣām viṣṇu tva sādhakam brahma para aneka prakaraṇa sandarbha rūpam sthānam
translated: For example, the collection of sections that proves the Vishnu nature of the words made of food etc., is stronger than the name of the Narayana hymn, May the made of food, the made of life-force, the made of mind, the made of knowledge, and the made of bliss be purified for me.

analyzed: etāni eva śruti ādinā artha nirṇaya sthalāni
translated: These are the places where the meaning is determined by scripture etc.

original: ādyayā samākhyayā nirṇetavyaṃ yathā puruṣasūktasamākhyayā vaiśvānarasya viṣṇutvam /
analyzed: ādyayā samākhyayā nirṇetavyam yathā puruṣasūkta samākhyayā vaiśvānarasya viṣṇu tvam
translated: That which is to be determined by the first name, such as the Vishnu nature of the all-pervading fire by the name of the Purusha hymn.

analyzed: dvitīyayā yathā ambhraṇī sūkta samākhyayā viśvakarma sūkta uktasya ajasya viṣṇu tvam
translated: By the second (argument), for example, by the name of the Ambhrini hymn, the existence of Vishnu in the sacrifice mentioned in the Vishvakarma hymn.

analyzed: astu evam tatas kim iti atas āha evam iti
translated: Having said this, what follows from that? In response to this, he says thus.

original: viruddhaiteṣāṃ samavāye sati prabalena pūrveṇottarabādhe ca sati 'āgamanirṇayaḥ' /
analyzed: viruddhā eteṣām samavāye sati prabalena pūrveṇa uttara bādhe ca sati āgama nirṇayaḥ
translated: When there is a conflict of these contradictory (arguments), and when the stronger (argument) overpowers the later (argument), then there is a decision regarding the scriptures.

analyzed: āgama arthasya vipratipannasya etaiḥ nirṇayaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the meaning of the scriptures, which is disputed, is decided by these (arguments).

analyzed: tat ca liṅgam viṣṇoḥ eva
translated: And that indication is of Vishnu alone.

analyzed: tasya eva prāṇa tva ukteḥ tat vai tvam prāṇo  abhavaḥ iti
translated: Because it is said that He alone is the vital air, You have become that vital air.

analyzed: nanu astu śruteḥ svabhāvataḥ prābalyam
translated: But let there be the natural superiority of the scriptures.

original: tathāpi bāhulyena pūrvapakṣyuktaliṅgānāmapi prābalyātsāmyenānirṇaya evetyata āha tacceti //
analyzed: tathā api bāhulyena pūrvapakṣi ukta liṅgānām api prābalyāt sāmyena anirṇayaḥ eva iti atas āha tat ca iti
translated: Even so, because of the superiority of the many indications stated by the opponent, there is only indecision due to equality. In response to this, he says that (and so on).

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of tu (but).

analyzed: liṅgam iti samudāya ekavacanam
translated: Indication is a collective singular.

analyzed: tathā ca tat
translated: And thus, that (indication).

analyzed: pūrva vādi uktam liṅga jātam tu viṣṇoḥ eva yuktam
translated: The group of indications stated by the previous proponent is proper only for Vishnu.

analyzed: na vāyoḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Not for Vayu, is the meaning.

original: tathā ca bāhulye 'pi liṅgānāṃ sāvakāśatvāttebhyaḥ śruterekasyā api niravakāśāyāḥ prābalyānnānirṇaya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca bāhulye liṅgānām sāvakāśa tvāt tebhyaḥ śruteḥ ekasyāḥ api niravakāśāyāḥ prābalyāt na anirṇayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, even though there are many indicatives, they are not decisive, because even one uncontradicted direct statement is stronger than them, even though it is contradicted by the many indicatives.

analyzed: nanu na liṅgam viṣṇau sa avakāśam
translated: But the indicatives are not contradicted by the direct statement.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣi udāhṛta samākhyā rūpa śruti antareṇa tasya prāṇa niṣṭhatayā eva uktatvāt iti atas āha tasya eva iti  tat vai tvam
translated: Because in another scripture, in the form of the identification cited by the pūrvapakṣin, it is stated that they refer to the individual soul only.🔽To this he says: Of that very one.

analyzed: iti śrutau tasya
translated: In the scripture That indeed is you.🔽Of that means of Viṣṇu.

analyzed: viṣṇoḥ prāṇa tvasya prāṇa śabda vācya tvasya ukteḥ ukta tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the statement of the individual soul as the prāṇa, as denoted by the word prāṇa, is stated.

analyzed: evam atas eva  iti atra ādhyātmika aśeṣa śabdasya samanvayam bruvatā tathā śāstra dṛṣṭyā
translated: Thus, in For this very reason,🔽the author of the aphorisms, by stating the identity of the word aśeṣa (entire) with the individual soul, and in From the point of view of scripture,

original: ityatrāntaryāmiparatvaṃ bruvatā sūtrakāreṇetaravyāvṛttyā tasyaiva prāṇatvokteḥ sādhitatvādityapi vyākhyeyametat /
analyzed: iti atra antaryāmi paratvam bruvatā sūtrakāreṇa itara vyāvṛttyā tasya eva prāṇa tva ukteḥ sādhita tvāt iti api vyākhyeyam etat
translated: by stating that it refers to the immanent one, has proved that the prāṇa is that very one, by excluding others. This should also be explained.

original: tathā ca śrutyantare prāṇaniṣṭhatayā liṅgasyoktāvapi na tadvirodhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śruti antare prāṇa niṣṭha tayā liṅgasya uktau api na tad virodhaḥ
translated: And thus, even though the indicatives are stated as referring to the individual soul in another scripture, there is no contradiction with that.

analyzed: tasya prāṇasya viṣṇu tva abhyupagamāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this is because Viṣṇu is accepted as the prāṇa.

analyzed: nanu tathā api kuvidaṅga

analyzed: iti ṛci vāyu niṣṭha tayā liṅga ukteḥ tad virodhaḥ iti asya api idam eva uttaram
translated: Thus, this is the same answer to the objection that there is a contradiction with the statement in the Ṛc that the Self is the wind.

analyzed: asmin pakṣe prāṇa tvam iti vāyu tvam upalakṣyate
translated: In this view, the statement it is the wind implies the statement it is the wind.

analyzed: tathā ca antar naye ādhidaivika aśeṣa śabda samanvayam bruvatā sūtrakāreṇa tasya eva  viṣṇoḥ eva prāṇa tva ukteḥ
translated: And in this way, in the Antarnaya, the author of the aphorisms, while speaking of the connection of all the words with the supreme deity, says of that alone.🔽The statement that it is the wind is a statement that it is denoted by the word wind.

analyzed: vāyu śabda vācya tva rūpa vāyutsya uktatvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is a statement that it is denoted by the word wind.

analyzed: tathā ca na tad virodhaḥ api iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus there is no contradiction with that either. This is the idea.

analyzed: na ca siddhānte sthāna apekṣayā prabalāt prakaraṇāt evam eva eṣaḥ
translated: And even in the established conclusion, by the context, which is stronger than the location, the word wind in the other scripture, It is thus,

analyzed: iti śruti antara gata prāṇa śabdasya
translated: of the word wind in the scripture,

analyzed: tathā yaḥ yam madhyamaḥ  iti asya tathā kuvidaṅga
translated: and the word wind in the mantra This middle one,

analyzed: iti mantra stha vāyu śabdasya mukhya vāyu para tvam
translated: and the word wind in the mantra O knower of the field,🔽are accepted as referring to the primary wind,

original: tatroktaliṅgānāmapi tatparatvamupetya teṣāṃ śrutyā bādhasyoktatvāt kathaṃ śrutyantarasthaprāṇavāyuśabdayoḥ viṣṇuparatvāṅgīkāreṇa samādhānam
analyzed: tatra ukta liṅgānām api tad paratvam upetya teṣām śrutyā bādhasya ukta tvāt katham śruti antara stha prāṇa vāyu śabdayoḥ viṣṇu paratva aṅgīkāreṇa samādhānam
translated: and since it has been said that the indications stated there are contradicted by the scripture, how is the solution by accepting that the words wind and life in the other scripture refer to Vishnu?

analyzed: atas eva candrikāyām

analyzed: na tu śruti antare madhyama śabda ukta prāṇa paraḥ iti uktam

analyzed: atas evam eva eṣaḥ praśna
translated: Therefore, the passage 'in the same way, this' (Kaṭha. 1.2.23)

original: iti vākyaṃ sthānātprakaraṇasya prābalye udāhṛtamiti vācyam /
analyzed: iti vākyam sthānāt prakaraṇasya prābalye udāhṛtam iti vācyam
translated: cannot be cited as an example of the superiority of context over place.

analyzed: ukta rītyā mukhyatas śruti antara gata prāṇa śabda ādeḥ brahma paratvena liṅgānām tad tad antaryāmi niṣṭhatve pi samākarṣa nyāyena anya paratvasya api aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because, in the above-mentioned way, the word 'prāṇa' in another Vedic text primarily refers to Brahman, and although the indicative marks are based on the individual Supreme Spirits, the acceptance of referring to something else by the rule of samākṣaranyāya,

original: śrutyantaroktaliṅgānāmanyaniṣṭhatve 'pi vā nānupapattiḥ /🔽na caivaṃ kāṭhakoktaliṅgānāmapyanyaniṣṭhatvāpattyā anyeṣāmīśānatvādyāpattiḥ /
analyzed: śruti antara ukta liṅgānām anya niṣṭha tve vā na anupapattiḥ  na ca evam kāṭhaka ukta liṅgānām api anya niṣṭhatva āpattyā anyeṣām īśāna tva ādi āpattiḥ

analyzed: niravakāśa śrutyā kāṭhaka ukta liṅgānām viṣṇu niṣṭha tā nirṇaya upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is logically possible to determine that the indicative marks mentioned in the Kaṭha Upaniṣad are based on Viṣṇu, by the Vedic text which is free from doubt.

analyzed: nanu tathā api katham īśānaḥ viṣṇuḥ bhavet śrutau īśānasya aṅguṣṭha parimita tva ukteḥ

analyzed: sarva gate ca harau tad ayogāt

original: na ca vyomavatsarvagatasyāpyaṇutvaṃ yujyata iti pratipāditamiti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca vyoma vat sarvagatasya api aṇu tvam yujyate iti pratipāditam iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that minuteness is proper even for the all-pervading one, like space, as has been explained.

analyzed: tathā api aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ
translated: Even so, he is of the size of a thumb.

analyzed: iti tanmātra parimāṇa tva ukteḥ ayogāt
translated: Because it is not proper to say that he is of that much size only.

original: na ca 'aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ' /🔽ityatra śrutaḥ parimāṇārthako mātracpratyaya eva /
analyzed: na ca aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ  iti atra śrutaḥ parimāṇa arthakaḥ mātrac pratyayaḥ eva
translated: And in the statement of the size of a thumb, the suffix matup denoting size is not used,

analyzed: na tu avadhāraṇa arthakaḥ mātra śabdaḥ
translated: but the word mātra meaning only.

analyzed: dehāṅguṣṭha mitaḥ dehe jīvāṅguṣṭha mitaḥ hṛdi
translated: Of the size of a thumb in the body, of the size of a thumb of the living being in the heart,

analyzed: iti smṛtau mitaḥ iti anena parimāṇasya eva ukteḥ
translated: in this smrti, mitah means of a certain size.

analyzed: tathā ca nā anupapattiḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that there is no inconsistency in this.

analyzed: tathātve ṅguṣṭha mātra tva abhidhātryām aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ
translated: If it were so, then in the scripture of the size of a thumb, which speaks of being of the size of a thumb,

analyzed: iti śrutau madhye ātmani  ityasya smṛtau hṛdi ityasya ca vaiyarthya āpātāt
translated: in the middle of the self,🔽in the smrti, and in the heart, would be meaningless.

analyzed: tanmātra parimita tva ukti artham hi tatra hṛdaya rūpa sūkṣma sthāna uktiḥ
translated: For the statement of the subtle place in the form of the heart is for the purpose of stating that he is of that much size only.

original: tasmādavadhāraṇārthakamātraśabda evāyamaṅgīkāryaḥ uktaṃ hi candrikāyām mātraśabdasyāvadhāraṇārthakatvāditi /
analyzed: tasmāt avadhāraṇa arthaka mātra śabdaḥ eva ayam aṅgīkāryaḥ uktam hi candrikāyām mātra śabdasya avadhāraṇa arthaka tvāt iti
translated: Therefore, this word 'only' should be accepted as having the meaning of restriction. For it has been said in the Candrika: Because the word 'only' has the meaning of restriction.

analyzed: sū om
translated: Sutra: ॐ.

analyzed: hṛdi apekṣayā tu manuṣya adhikāra tvāt
translated: But the statement of Vishnu's being of the size of a thumb is appropriate in the heart, because men are entitled to it.

analyzed: om
translated: Om.🔽🔽

analyzed: sarva gatasya api tasya aṅguṣṭha mātra tvam hṛdi avakāśa apekṣayā yujyate
translated: Even though He is all-pervading, His being of the size of a thumb is appropriate in relation to the space in the heart.

original: tathā ca sarvagate harāvaṅguṣṭhamātratvoktiranupapanneti nātreśāno viṣṇurityāśaṅkāṃ pariharatsūtramupanyasya tadakṣarāṇi vyācaṣṭe hṛdīti
analyzed: tathā ca sarvagate harau aṅguṣṭha mātra tva uktiḥ anupapannā iti na atra īśānaḥ viṣṇuḥ iti āśaṅkām pariharat sūtram upanyasya tad akṣarāṇi vyācaṣṭe hṛdi iti
translated: Thus, the statement of all-pervading Hari being of the size of a thumb is inappropriate. Therefore, the doubt that Ishana here is not Vishnu is being removed. The sutra is presented and its words are explained as 'in the heart'.

analyzed: sarvagatasya api iti anena tuśabdaḥ yadi api tathā api iti arthatayā vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By the words 'even though all-pervading', the word 'but' is explained as having the meaning of 'although'.

analyzed: hṛdi apekṣayā iti anena sūcita hetoḥ anvaya yogyam sādhyam darśayati tasya iti
translated: By the words 'in relation to the heart', the conclusion suitable for the reason indicated is shown by the words 'of Him'.

analyzed: yojanā tu yadi api viṣṇuḥ sarva gataḥ tathā api tasya aṅguṣṭha mātra tvam
translated: The plan is this: Although Vishnu is all-pervading, still 'His being of the size of a thumb'.

analyzed: aṅguṣṭha mātra tva uktiḥ yujyate
translated: The statement of being of the size of a thumb is appropriate.

analyzed: katham yatas hṛdi avakāśa upekṣayā
translated: How? Because 'in relation to the space in the heart'.

analyzed: hṛdi vidyamānaḥ yaḥ yam avakāśaḥ ṅguṣṭha parimita deśaḥ tad apekṣayā tatra abhivyakta tāvat paribhita bhagavat mūrti viśeṣam apekṣya tasya viṣṇoḥ aṅguṣṭha mātra tvam
translated: The fact that Vishnu is of the size of a thumb is in relation to a particular form of the Lord that is manifested there, in the space in the heart, which is the size of a thumb.

analyzed: asti atas iti
translated: It exists thus.

analyzed: yat vā hṛdi avakāśa apekṣayā
translated: Or, in relation to the space in the heart.

original: hṛdi vidyamānāvakāśamapekṣya tatsambandhāttasyāṅguṣṭhamātratvavacanaṃ yujyata ityāvṛttiṃ vinā yojanā /
analyzed: hṛdi vidyamāna avakāśam apekṣya tad sambandhāt tasya aṅguṣṭha mātra tva vacanam yujyate iti āvṛttim vinā yojanā
translated: In relation to the space that exists in the heart, the statement that He is of the size of a thumb is appropriate due to its connection with that. The sentence is construed without repetition.

original: prathamapakṣe śaktyāparimite 'pi bhagavati mūrtiviśeṣe vyaktyātmanāṅguṣṭhamātratvasya sthānini brahmaṇi tatsambandhādupacāreṇoktiriti bhedaḥ
analyzed: prathama pakṣe śaktyā aparimite bhagavati mūrti viśeṣe vyakti ātmanā aṅguṣṭha mātra tvasya sthānini brahmaṇi tad sambandhāt upacāreṇa uktiḥ iti bhedaḥ
translated: In the first case, even though the Lord is unlimited by power, in a particular form, the statement by way of superimposition is made in relation to Brahman, which is the substratum of the size of a thumb by way of manifestation. This is the difference.

original: atra ṭīkāyāṃ hṛdyavakāśāpekṣayeti bhāṣyaṃ sāvadhāraṇaṃ kṛtvā sautratuśabdo 'vadhāraṇatayā vyākhyātaḥ /
analyzed: atra ṭīkāyām hṛdi avakāśa apekṣayā iti bhāṣyam sāvadhāraṇam kṛtvā sautra tuśabdaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: Here, in the commentary, the commentary in relation to the space in the heart is made restrictive, and the word tu in the sutra is explained as restrictive.

analyzed: tena viṣṇo uṅguṣṭha mātra tvam hṛdi apekṣayā eva
translated: By that, the fact that Vishnu is of the size of a thumb is only in relation to the heart.

analyzed: na tu loka vat paricchinna tvāt iti uktam bhavati
translated: It is not said that He is limited like the world due to being limited.

original: tattatsthāneṣu vyaktamūrtiviśeṣāpekṣayā vā upacāreṇa vā tattatparimāṇatvoktyā 'yastvetameva prādeśamātram' / chāṃ / /
analyzed: tad tad sthāneṣu vyakta mūrti viśeṣa apekṣayā vā upacāreṇa vā tad tad parimāṇa tva uktyā yaḥ tu etam eva prādeśa mātram chāṃ
translated: Or, in relation to the particular manifest form in those places, or figuratively, by stating that it has those dimensions, as in the Chāndogya: He who is this much, just a span.🔽A person of the size of a span.

analyzed: iti chāndogye prādeśa mātram puruṣam  iti anyatra prādeśaḥ puruṣa uttamaḥ
translated: A span is the best person.

analyzed: iti aparatra ca hṛd gatasya viṣṇoḥ prādeśa parimita tva ukteḥ
translated: Thus, elsewhere, it is said that Viṣṇu residing in the heart is of the size of a span.

analyzed: aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ puruṣaḥ ṅguṣṭham ca samāśritaḥ
translated: The person who is the size of a thumb, and who rests on the thumb.

analyzed: iti śruti antare aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: In another scripture, The person who is the size of a thumb.

analyzed: iti kaṭhavalyām ca aṅguṣṭha mātraḥ puruṣaḥ  iti aparatra ca aṅguṣṭha parimita tva ukteḥ aṅguṣṭha agra pramāṇakaḥ
translated: And in the Kaṭha Upaniṣad, The person who is the size of a thumb.🔽And elsewhere, it is said that he is the size of a thumb. He is the size of the tip of a thumb.

original: iti kvacidaṅguṣṭhāgrapramāṇakatvoktervirodha iti codyaṃ parihṛtaṃ bhavati /

analyzed: tasmāt māna abhāvena āpti tad mūla tva aniścayāt veda anitya tve tad prāmāṇya abhāva āpatteḥ na nitya tva śruteḥ upacarita artha tvam vācyam iti bhāvaḥ

analyzed: na kevalam śruteḥ veda nitya tva siddhiḥ

analyzed: kintu pariśeṣa anumānāt api iti āha nitya tva iti

analyzed: mūlapramāṇasya nitya tva apekṣa tvāt vedasya nitya tva avagamāt iti anvayaḥ

analyzed: anyathā anāśvāsāt yajña ādeḥ puṇya sādhanatā ādi bodhakam veda mūlam ca bhavat pratyakṣa anumānayoḥ asambhavāt pariśeṣāt vākyam eva iti vācyam
translated: Otherwise, since the Veda which teaches the means of merit such as sacrifice etc. cannot be the basis of perception and inference, it must be said to be a sentence by the remaining.

analyzed: tasya ca anitya tām upetya mūla anveṣaṇe navasthā āpattyā nitya tvam eva vācyam
translated: And since its non-eternality is accepted, in the search for the basis, there would be an infinite regress, so its eternality must be said.

analyzed: tatas varam vedasya eva nitya tva aṅgīkaraṇam
translated: Therefore, it is better to accept the eternality of the Veda itself.

analyzed: śruti siddha tvāt iti

analyzed: svatas prāmāṇya prasiddheḥ ca nitya tvāt vedasya tad uditānām

original: tathā tasya nityatve 'pyāptoktatvarūpaguṇajanyatvābhāvena prāmāṇyābhāvāpattiriti samaṃ bādhakamityata āha svata iti //

translated: similarly, even in the case of its eternality, the absence of authoritativeness due to the absence of being produced by the quality in the form of being spoken by a trustworthy person is a contradiction. Thus the contradiction is the same. In response to this, he says 'by itself,' etc.

analyzed: vedasya iti anuvartate

analyzed: tathā ca vedasya

analyzed: veda janya jñāna gata yāthārthya rūpa prāmāṇyasya svatas eva  jñāna sāmānya kāraṇāt eva prasiddheḥ
translated: The authoritativeness, which is the truthfulness of the knowledge produced by the Veda, is 'well-established by itself alone.'🔽'Because of the possibility,' i.e., because of being known.

analyzed: upapatteḥ pramita tvāt iti arthaḥ

analyzed: yat vā veda gata yathārtha jñāna karaṇa tva rūpa karaṇa prāmāṇyasya svatas eva

analyzed: jñāna karaṇa tva sahaja śakti abhinna yathārtha jñāna janaka tva śakti rūpa tvena eva pramita tvāt iti arthaḥ

analyzed: asya api vedasya nitya tva sambhavāt iti anena anvayaḥ

original: tathā ca vedasya nityatvasya siddhatvāttadvācyadevānāmanityatve vācyahīnatvarūpāprāmāṇyāpattiriti bhāvaḥ /

translated: And thus, since the eternality of the Veda is established, if the deities denoted by it are non-eternal, there would be the fault of invalidity in the form of deficiency of what is denoted.

analyzed: punar anya bhāva niyama abhāvāt ca śabde virodhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there is contradiction in the word due to the absence of the restriction of the existence of another,

analyzed: tasya niyame pramāṇa abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no proof for the restriction of that.

analyzed: atīta devatā pravāhe tu pramāṇam asti iti vaiṣamyam iti bhāvaḥ

From the word for this very reason,

original: na ca phale 'tiśayasya siddhatvena tatrārthitvasambhave 'pi tatsādhanavidyānāṃ nityasiddhatvāt vidyāvicārasya jñānārthatvāt tatrārthitvāsambhava

analyzed: nanu astu evam asambhavāt iti ukta yukti parābhavaḥ

analyzed: jaimini abhimatam iti arthaḥ

analyzed: pautrāyaṇam prati raikka ukteḥ tad kartṛka sambodhanāt eva iti arthaḥ

analyzed: anadhikāriṇam prati muneḥ upadeśa asambhavāt

analyzed: pautrāyaṇasya arthāt śrutau adhikāra ukteḥ ca iti vā yojanā

analyzed: sa yuktika pūrvapakṣaḥ ca darśitaḥ bhavati

original: chāndogye caturthādhyāye saṃvargaprakaraṇe hītthamākhyāyikā pautrāyaṇo nāma rājā prāsādāgre niśāyāṃ śayāno 'bhūt /
analyzed: chāndogye caturtha adhyāye saṃvarga prakaraṇe hi ittham ākhyāyikā pautrāyaṇaḥ nāma rājā prāsāda agre niśāyām śayānaḥ bhūt
translated: In the fourth chapter of the Chandogya, in the section on the union of the soul with Brahman, there is this story: King Pautrayana was sleeping on the top of his palace at night.

analyzed: tadā prāsāda upari haṃsa pakṣiṇaḥ gaman
translated: At that time, geese flew over the palace.

original: uparipatatāṃ parasparaṃ vārtāṃ kurvatāṃ teṣāṃ madhye dvāvagragāmināvāstām /

translated: Among them, two were flying in front, conversing with each other.

analyzed: tatra ekaḥ ekam uvāca
translated: One of them said to the other:

analyzed: kim iti are pautrāyaṇīyam tejaḥ tvam mā agamaḥ
translated: What? O Pautrayana, you are coming to that light.

analyzed: tad sambandhe tadīyam tejaḥ tvām dahet iti
translated: If you come in contact with it, its light will burn you.

translated: Thus addressed, the other swan, with the word kim expressing reproach, disregarding the king, praised the sage Raikva alone.

analyzed: tat śrutvā paritapta manāḥ rājā talpāt utthitaḥ tvarayā sva sārathim āhūya raikva gaveṣaṇāya ādideśa
translated: Hearing that, the king, with a troubled mind, rose from his seat and quickly summoned his charioteer, instructing him to search for Raikva.

original: sa tatra tatra raikvamanviṣyan nāvidamiti prathamamāgataḥ /
analyzed: sa tatra tatra raikvam anviṣyan na avidam iti prathamam āgataḥ
translated: Having searched for Raikva here and there, he first came back saying I did not find him.

original: punastallakṣaṇoktipūrvakaṃ rājñā tanmārgaṇāyādiṣṭaḥ punaranviyaṣya kvacitpradeśe raikvamavalokya punā rājānaṃ pratyetyāha raikvamavidamiti
analyzed: punar tad lakṣaṇa ukti pūrvakam rājñā tad mārgaṇāya ādiṣṭaḥ punar anviyaṣya kvacid pradeśe raikvam avalokya rājānam pratyetya āha raikvam avidam iti
translated: Again, instructed by the king to search for him, having searched for him again, having seen Raikva in a certain place, he came back to the king again and said I found Raikva.

analyzed: yathāvṛttam avadat
translated: He told the story as it happened.

original: tadā rājā svasārathivacanena raikvamunisthānaṃ niścitya tasmāttattvaṃ vividiṣurgurudakṣiṇāṃ gṛhītvā tatsamīpaṃ jagāma /

original: tathā ca pautrāyaṇanidarśanenaiva śūdrasya vedavidyādhikārasiddhirityāśaṅkāṃ pariharatsūtramupanyasya vyācaṣṭe kṣatriyatveti /🔽atra 'ayam' / ityataḥ prāk 'uttaratra' /
analyzed: tathā ca pautrāyaṇa nidarśanena eva śūdrasya veda vidyā adhikāra siddhiḥ iti āśaṅkām pariharat sūtram upanyasya vyācaṣṭe kṣatriya tva iti  atra ayam iti atas prāk uttaratra
translated: And thus, by the very example of Pautrayana, the right of a Shudra to the knowledge of the Vedas is established. To remove this doubt, he presents the sutra and explains it with Kshatriya-ness.

analyzed: iti sautra padam sambandhanīyam
translated: Here, before this, the sutra word uttaratra (in the next sentence) should be connected.

analyzed: śrutena iti śeṣaḥ

original: tathā ca uttaratra raikvaṃ prati pautrāyaṇasya ādravaṇāt /
analyzed: tathā ca uttaratra raikvam prati pautrāyaṇasya ādravaṇāt
translated: And thus, because Pautrayana runs after Raikva in the next sentence,

analyzed: uttaratra tad pratipādana anantaram
translated: in the next sentence, after that is taught.

analyzed: yat vā śūdra śabdena sambodhanāt uttaratra ayam aśvatarī rathaḥ
translated: Or, because he is addressed by the word Shudra, in the next sentence, this is the chariot with a mare,

analyzed: iti śrutena iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is by the mentioned.

original: pautrāyaṇena dīyamānasya rathasya anyadīyatvaśaṅkānirāsāya sūtre caitraratheneti bhāvapradhānapadaṃ prayuktam /
analyzed: pautrāyaṇena dīyamānasya rathasya anyadīya tva śaṅkā nirāsāya sūtre caitrarathena iti bhāva pradhāna padam prayuktam
translated: In the sutra, the word Chaitra-ratha is used as a substantive to remove the doubt that the chariot being given by Pautrayana belongs to someone else.

analyzed: anyathā citrarathena iti eva avakṣyat
translated: Otherwise, he would have said Chitra-ratha only.

original: tatra citraścāsau rathaśca citrarathaḥ tasyāyaṃ caitraratha iti vigrahamabhipretya pratyayārthaṃ pradarśayan tadvyācaṣṭe citrarathasambandhitveneti
analyzed: tatra citraḥ ca asau rathaḥ ca citrarathaḥ tasya ayam caitrarathaḥ iti vigraham abhipretya pratyaya artham pradarśayan tat vyācaṣṭe citra ratha sambandhi tvena iti
translated: There, Chitra and ratha are Chitra-ratha. This belongs to him, so it is Chaitra-ratha. Having intended this analysis, he displays the meaning of the suffix and explains it as by the relation to Chitra-ratha.

analyzed: svābhāvika citraratha sambandhi tvena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: by the relation of being connected with the variegated chariot naturally.

analyzed: atra ratha mātram eva liṅgam
translated: Here, only the chariot itself is the inferential mark.

original: citrapadaṃ tu svarūpakathanārtham /🔽yadvā apūrvarathayogena kṣatriyatvasambhāvanārthaṃ tatpadam /🔽athavā yadā rathitvenaiva kṣatriyatvasya niścayaḥ /
analyzed: citra padam tu svarūpa kathana artham  yat vā apūrva ratha yogena kṣatriya tva sambhāvanā artham tat padam  athavā yadā rathi tvena eva kṣatriya tvasya niścayaḥ
translated: But the word 'variegated' is for the purpose of stating the nature.🔽Or, that word is for the purpose of inferring Kshatriya-hood by the connection with an unprecedented chariot.🔽Or, when Kshatriya-hood is ascertained by chariot-hood itself,

analyzed: tadā sutarām citrarathi tvena iti sūcana artham tat padam
translated: then that word is for the purpose of indicating that it is all the more so by variegated chariot-hood.

analyzed: yadi api ayam aśvatarī rathaḥ
translated: Although in 'this is the chariot of the mule',

analyzed: iti atra citraratha mātra śravaṇe na tad sambandhaḥ sya śrūyate
translated: even when only the variegated chariot is heard, its relation is not heard.

original: tathāpi tatpūrvavākye 'hāretvā tavaiva' /🔽iti ṣaṣṭhyā itvāśabdārtharathasambandho gamyata iti tasyāśca rathasambandhe śrutirūpatvāt yuktamuktam /
analyzed: tathā api tad pūrva vākye tava eva  iti ṣaṣṭhyā itvā śabda artha ratha sambandhaḥ gamyate iti tasyāḥ ca ratha sambandhe śruti rūpa tvāt yuktam uktam
translated: Nevertheless, in the preceding sentence 'having brought it for you',🔽by the genitive case, the relation with the chariot is understood as the meaning of the word 'having brought'. Since that relation with the chariot is in the form of direct statement, what is said is proper.

original: citro ratho yasyeti citrarathastasya bhāvaḥ caitrarathasteneti vyākhyānaṃ tu bhāve 'ṇ pratyayasya kalpyatvāt śrutibhāṣyaviruddhatvācca ayuktam/
analyzed: citraḥ rathaḥ yasya iti citra rathaḥ tasya bhāvaḥ caitra rathaḥ tena iti vyākhyānam tu bhāve ṇ pratyayasya kalpya tvāt śruti bhāṣya viruddha tvāt ca ayuktam
translated: But the explanation that 'he who has a variegated chariot is Citraratha, the state of that is Chaitraratha, by that' is improper, because the suffix 'an' in the state has to be assumed, and because it contradicts the direct statement and the commentary.

original: na ca caitraratheneti sambandhoktimātreṇa kathamanyadīyatvaśaṅkānirāsa iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca caitrarathena iti sambandha ukti mātreṇa katham anyadīya tva śaṅkā nirāsaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that the mere statement of the connection with 'Caitraratha' does not remove the doubt of belonging to another.

original: svataḥ prāptatadīyatve bādhakābhāve tadīyatvasyaiva svābhāvikatvasambhave naimittikagrahaṇāyogāt /
analyzed: svatas prāpta tadīya tve bādhaka abhāve tadīya tvasya eva svābhāvika tva sambhave naimittika grahaṇa ayogāt
translated: For when there is no contradiction in the natural belonging to that which is obtained by itself, it is possible that belonging to that is natural itself, and it is not proper to take it as occasional.

analyzed: sva tva abhāve dhana ayogāt
translated: Because without ownership, wealth is not possible.

analyzed: ityādi nyāya prāpta tvāt
translated: Because it is obtained by the reasoning beginning with this.

original: rathena liṅgādityanayossāmānādhikaraṇyāya liṅgāditi pañcamī vyatyayena vyācaṣṭe liṅganeti /🔽pautrāyaṇasyetyetat asyetyanuvṛttapadasya arthakathanam /
analyzed: rathena liṅgāt iti anayoḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyāya liṅgāt iti pañcamī vyatyayena vyācaṣṭe liṅganā iti  pautrāyaṇasya iti etat asya iti anuvṛtta padasya artha kathanam
translated: For the sake of co-reference with 'by the chariot' and 'by the mark', he explains the fifth case 'by the mark' by transposition.🔽'Of Pautramāyana' explains the repeated word 'of this'.

original: kṣatriyatvāvagaterityasya śucā'dravaṇādevāsya śūdratvaṃ na tu rūḍhyeti pūrveṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: kṣatriya tva avagateḥ iti asya śucā adravaṇāt eva asya śūdra tvam na tu rūḍhyā iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ

analyzed: caśabdaḥ liṅgena ca iti sambadhyate  tena bahu dāyī
translated: The word 'ca' is connected with 'and by the mark'.🔽Therefore, the mark stated in the remaining sentence 'he who gives much'

analyzed: ityādi vākya śeṣa uktam liṅgam samuccīyate
translated: is combined.

original: liṅgasya śrutitaścaramatvena anekatvena ca prābalyasūcanāya vā caśabdaḥ /
analyzed: liṅgasya śrutitaḥ carama tvena aneka tvena ca prābalya sūcanāya vā caśabdaḥ
translated: The word 'ca' is used to indicate the strength of the mark by its being heard last and by its being many.

analyzed: evam sūtre pi caśabdaḥ bhinnakramaḥ ukta prayojanakaḥ ca
translated: In the same way, the word 'ca' in the sutra also has a different sequence and the same purpose as stated.

original: evaṃ ca rūḍhereva prābalye 'pyatra śrutānekaliṅgarūpabādhakāt śūdraśabdasya yogavṛttyaṅgīkāra eva yukta iti bhāvaḥ /🔽'gardabhādaśvāyāṃ jātā aśvataryaḥ' /
analyzed: evam ca rūḍheḥ eva prābalye pi atra śruta aneka liṅga rūpa bādhakāt śūdra śabdasya yoga vṛtti aṅgīkāraḥ eva yuktaḥ iti bhāvaḥ  gardabhāt aśvāyām jātāḥ aśvataryaḥ
translated: Thus, even though the established meaning is stronger, it is proper to accept the figurative usage of the word Śūdra here due to the contradiction in the form of the many genders mentioned in the text. This is the idea.

analyzed: iti tattvapradīpe  gardabhīṣu aśvaiḥ jātāḥ asvataryaḥ
translated: In the Tattvadipikā: The mules are born from a mare to a donkey.

analyzed: iti vyāsatīrthīye
translated: In the Vyāsatithi: The mules are born from mares to donkeys.

original: tadyukto rathaḥ aśvatarīrathaḥ tava dakṣiṇātvena vartate ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tad yuktaḥ rathaḥ aśvatarī rathaḥ tava dakṣiṇā tvena vartate iti arthaḥ
translated: A chariot equipped with that is an Aśvatarī chariot. It is said to be on your right side as the sacrificial fee.

analyzed: raikvam prati pautrāyaṇa vākyam etat

analyzed: rathaḥ tu aśvatarī yuktaḥ citraḥ iti abhidhīyate iti brāhme
translated: A chariot equipped with mules is called Citra. This is in the Brāhmaṇa.

original: nanu śrutāvaśvatarīrathaśabdaprayogāt sūtre 'pi tathaiva prayoktavye kathaṃ sūtrakṛt
analyzed: nanu śrutau aśvatarī ratha śabda prayogāt sūtre tathā eva prayoktavye katham sūtra kṛt
translated: Now, since the words Aśvatarī chariot are used in the Śruti, how is it that the author of the sūtra

analyzed: citraratha śabdam prāyuṅta iti āśaṅkya ubhayoḥ artha aikyāt na visaṃvādaḥ iti āśayena tatra abhidhānam āha rathaḥ iti

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ vā

analyzed: na tu ratha tvasya api śakya koṭi praveśaḥ

original: tathā ca sūtre rathatvaprakārakabodhāya rathaśabdaprayoga iti na tadvaiyarthyamiti dhyeyam iti brāhme uktatvāt na śrutisūtrayorvairūpyamityupaskāreṇānvayaḥ
analyzed: tathā ca sūtre ratha tva prakāraka bodhāya ratha śabda prayogaḥ iti na tad vaiyarthyam iti dhyeyam iti brāhme ukta tvāt na śruti sūtrayoḥ vairūpyam iti upaskāreṇa anvayaḥ
translated: And thus, it should be understood that in the sutra, the word ratha is used for the purpose of conveying the knowledge of the type of chariot, so its redundancy is not a problem. This is stated in the Brahme. Therefore, there is no difference between the shruti and the sutra. This is the connection with the commentary.

original: yatra vedo rathastatra na vedo yatra no rathaḥ /
analyzed: yatra vedaḥ rathaḥ tatra na vedaḥ yatra no rathaḥ
translated: Where there is the Veda, there is the chariot. Where there is no chariot, there is no Veda.

analyzed: iti brahmavaivarte  /
translated: Thus it is said in the Brahmavaivarta Purana.

original: evaṃ sākṣādeva svābhāvikarathena pautrāyaṇasya kṣatriyatvaṃ prasādhitam /
analyzed: evam sākṣāt eva svābhāvika rathena pautrāyaṇasya kṣatriya tvam prasādhitam
translated: Thus, the Kshatriya nature of Pautrayana is directly established by his natural chariot.

original: svābhāvikarathitve 'sya varṇāvaratvaṃ kiṃ na syādityaprayojakatvamāśaṅkya maivamāgantukasyāpi rathasya vedaṃ vināyogāt 'vedasya ca saṃskāreti 🔽vakṣyamāṇanyāyena śūdre 'yogāt' /

translated: Fearing the irrelevance of his natural chariot, the question arises - why should he not be of a lower caste? The answer is - no, because even the adventitious chariot is not possible without the Veda, and because of the reasoning to be stated later that the Shudra is not fit for the Vedic rites.

original: rathamātreṇa vedānumānadvārā pautrāyaṇasya śūdratvābhāvasiddherityāśayena rathena vedānumāne vyabhicāraśaṅkāparihārāya āgamenobhayavyāptiṃ
analyzed: ratha mātreṇa veda anumāna dvārā pautrāyaṇasya śūdra tva abhāva siddheḥ iti āśayena rathena veda anumāne vyabhicāra śaṅkā parihārāya āgamena ubhaya vyāptim
translated: By the mere chariot, the non-Shudratva of Pautrayana is established through the inference of the Veda. With this idea, in order to remove the doubt of deviation in the inference of the Veda by the chariot, the all-pervasiveness of both is shown by the scripture.

analyzed: darśayati yatra iti
translated: He says where etc.

analyzed: tatra tatra eva iti arthaḥ
translated: 'There' means there itself.

original: tena yatra vahniḥ tatraiva dhūma ityādāviva vedasya vyāpakatālābhaḥ/
analyzed: tena yatra vahniḥ tatra eva dhūmaḥ ityādau iva vedasya vyāpaka tā alābhaḥ
translated: Thus, like in the case of 'where there is fire, there is smoke', the Veda is established as the pervader.

original: ata eva vyatirekapradarśakāṃśe na veda iti vedabhāvasya prathamamuktiḥ/
analyzed: atas eva vyatireka pradarśaka aṃśe na vedaḥ iti veda bhāvasya prathama muktiḥ
translated: For this very reason, in the part showing the negative concomitance, the absence of the Veda is mentioned first.

analyzed: smṛtau ratha śabdena āgantuka svābhāvika sādhāraṇa ratha mātrasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: In the Smriti, the word 'ratha' (chariot) is intended to denote just a chariot, which is common to both the adventitious and natural.

original: samavyāptyabhiprāyeṇa vā yatra veda ityuktiḥ /🔽ata eva ṭīkāyāṃ 'rathasya vedāvinābhāvāt' /
analyzed: sama vyāpti abhiprāyeṇa vā yatra vedaḥ iti uktiḥ  atas eva ṭīkāyām rathasya veda avinābhāvāt
translated: Or, the statement 'where there is Veda' is made with the intention of showing equal pervasion.🔽For this very reason, in the commentary, it is said 'because the chariot is invariably concomitant with the Veda'.

analyzed: iti rathasya vyāpya tvam uktvā vaidika tva mātre vidyamānam rathi tvam
translated: Having stated that the chariot is the pervaded, it is said by 'the mere quality of having a chariot, which is present in the mere quality of being Vedic',

analyzed: iti anena tasya vyāpaka tvam uktam
translated: that it is the pervader.

original: vastutastu yatra rathastatra veda iti yojanāyāṃ nānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: vastutas tu yatra rathaḥ tatra vedaḥ iti yojanāyām na anupapattiḥ
translated: But in reality, there is no inconsistency in the construction 'where there is a chariot, there is the Veda'.

original: tathā ca anena vyāptiniścayāt na vyabhicāraśaṅketi yādṛśatādṛśarathamātreṇa vedānumānadvārā śūdratvābhāvaniścayānna pautrāyaṇasya vedabāhyavarṇāvaratvaṃ
analyzed: tathā ca anena vyāpti niścayāt na vyabhicāra śaṅkā iti yādṛśa tādṛśa ratha mātreṇa veda anumāna dvārā śūdra tva abhāva niścayān na pautrāyaṇasya veda bāhya varṇa avara tvam
translated: And thus, because the certainty of pervasion is obtained in this way, there is no doubt of a counterexample. By the inference of the Veda through just any kind of chariot, the absence of being a Shudra is ascertained. Therefore, the inferiority of the external caste of Pautrayana to the Veda

analyzed: śaṅkyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: should not be suspected. This is the meaning.

original: etena pūrvapakṣiṇā śūdre 'pi vedāṅgīkārānna tena śūdratvābhāvasādhanaṃ yuktamitinirastaṃ /
analyzed: etena pūrvapakṣiṇā śūdre pi veda aṅgīkārāt na tena śūdra tva abhāva sādhanam yuktam iti nirastam
translated: By this (argument) the opponent's view that it is not proper to prove the absence of Śūdra-ness by that (verse) even in a Śūdra, because of the acceptance of the Vedas (by him), is refuted.

analyzed: tasya uttara sūtre nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because that (view) will be refuted in the next aphorism.

original: na ca brāhmaṇādisādhāraṇarathitvenāsya vaidikatvaniścaye 'pi taddvārā aśūdratvasiddhāvapi kathaṃ kṣatriyatvaniścaya iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca brāhmaṇa ādi sādhāraṇa rathi tvena asya vaidika tva niścaye tad dvārā a śūdra tva siddhau api katham kṣatriya tva niścayaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that even when this (verse) is ascertained to be Vedic by the commonality of being about a chariot with a Brāhmaṇa etc., and even when Śūdra-ness is not established by that (commonality), how is the certainty of Kṣatriya-ness (established)?

analyzed: rathi tva mātrasya vaidika tva vyāpta tva uktyā svābhāvika rathi tvasya vaidika viśeṣa kṣatriya tva vyāpta tvena api smṛti abhipreta tvāt
translated: Because it is intended by the Smṛti that the mere fact of being about a chariot is pervaded by being Vedic, and that the natural fact of being about a chariot is pervaded by the special Vedic Kṣatriya-ness.

original: tasya ca kādācitkarathavati brāhmaṇādāvabhāvāttena sākṣādeva kṣatriyatvaniścayopapattiḥ /🔽na ca 'apalāyanaṃ ca śūdrasya' /
analyzed: tasya ca kādācitka rathavati brāhmaṇa ādau abhāvāt tena sākṣāt eva kṣatriya tva niścaya upapattiḥ  na ca apalāyanam ca śūdrasya
translated: And because that (natural fact of being about a chariot) does not exist in a Brāhmaṇa etc. who sometimes have a chariot, the certainty of Kṣatriya-ness is logically established by that (natural fact of being about a chariot) itself.

original: ityanena prāptayoddhṛtvānyathānupapattyā śūdrasya rathitvapratītestatra vyabhicāra iti vācyam /
analyzed: iti anena prāptayā uddhṛ tva anyathā anupapattyā śūdrasya rathi tva pratīteḥ tatra vyabhicāraḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that there is an inconstancy (of the reason) because the fact of being about a chariot is understood in a Śūdra by the non-applicability of anything else than fighting, by (the rule) 'And not running away for a Śūdra'.

analyzed: apalāyanena yoddhṛ tvasya padāti tayā upapattyā rathi tva an ākṣepaka tvāt
translated: Because the fact of being about a chariot is not adduced by the non-applicability of fighting by means of foot-soldiers by not running away.

original: brahmavaivarta ityasya uktatvādityadhyāhāreṇa nāsau śūdra ityanenānvayaḥ iti jñāyata iti śeṣaḥ anena 'ādravaṇāt' /
analyzed: brahmavaivarte iti asya ukta tvāt iti adhyāhāreṇa na asau śūdraḥ iti anena anvayaḥ iti jñāyate iti śeṣaḥ anena ādravaṇāt
translated: It is understood that the connection is with 'he is not a Shudra' by supplying the words 'because it has been said' to the sentence 'Brahma-vaivarta'. The rest is understood. By this (verse), 'because of running'.

analyzed: sambodhanāt vai uttaratra
translated: Or, because of the vocative 'in the latter part'.

analyzed: ayam aśvatarī rathaḥ
translated: 'This is the chariot of Ashvatara'.

original: itiśrutena 'caitrarathena liṅgāt' /🔽liṅgena svābhāvikarathena liṅgena bahudāyitvādiliṅgena cāsya pautrāyaṇasya kṣatriyatvāvagateḥ /
analyzed: iti śrutena caitrarathena liṅgāt  liṅgena svābhāvika rathena liṅgena bahu dāyi tva ādi liṅgena ca asya pautrāyaṇasya kṣatriya tva avagateḥ
translated: By the Vedic text 'because of the indication by Caitraratha'.🔽Because of the indication by the chariot which is natural to him, and because of the many indications such as being very generous, the Kshatriya nature of this grandson is understood.

analyzed: asmāt bādhakāt tad ādravaṇāt nimittāt eva asya śūdra tvam
translated: From this contradiction, his Shudra nature is only because of that reason of running.

analyzed: na tu jātyā asau śūdraḥ
translated: But he is not a Shudra by birth.

original: tathā rathena vedaniścayācca nāsau śūdra iti sūtrārtha ukto bhavati /
analyzed: tathā rathena veda niścayāt ca na asau śūdraḥ iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus, the meaning of the sutra is stated: because of the chariot and because of the certainty of the Vedas, he is not a Shudra.

analyzed: sū om
translated: The sutra is: ॐ.

analyzed: saṃskāra parāmarśāt tad abhāva abhilāpāt ca
translated: Because of the reference to the sacraments and because of the statement of the absence of those.

analyzed: om
translated: Om.🔽🔽

analyzed: aṣṭa varṣam brāhmaṇam upanayīta tam adhyāpayīta
translated: 'One should initiate a Brahmana at the age of eight and teach him.'

analyzed: iti adhyayana artham saṃskāra parāmarśāt

translated: Therefore, there is no contradiction with that either. To remove this doubt, he quotes the sutra and explains it with tad-abhavat.

analyzed: iti satya vacanena
translated: By the statement of truth.

analyzed: vāc manasayoḥ eka rūpa yathārtha vacanena tad jñāpitena ārjavena iti yāvat
translated: By the true statement of the same form of speech and mind, that is, by the straightforwardness indicated by that.

analyzed: satyakāmasya  tad ākhyasya ṛṣeḥ etat ca pūrvatra uttaratra ca sambadhyate
translated: Of Satyakama.

analyzed: satya vacanena satya kāmasya
translated: This is connected with the previous and subsequent statements. By the statement of truth of Satyakama.

original: ityādinā sūtre tacchabdo vyastaḥ anekavibhaktikaḥ buddhyā vivicyāvartate ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ityādinā sūtre tad śabdaḥ vyastaḥ aneka vibhaktikaḥ buddhyā vivicya āvartate iti uktam bhavati
translated: Thus, in the sutra, the word tat is divided into many case endings, and it is said that it is repeated by the intellect.

analyzed: śūdra tva abhāva nirdhāraṇe ca ityasya na etat brāhmaṇaḥ iti anena sambandhaḥ
translated: And in the determination of the absence of being a Shudra, this is connected with he is not a Brahmin.

analyzed: caḥ va dhāraṇe  śrutau abrāhmaṇa mātrasya an upanayana abhiprāya pratīteḥ tad anusāreṇa brāhmaṇa tva abhāva iti an uktvā
translated: Cha is for determination.🔽Since in the Veda, the mere non-Brahmin is understood to be the one who is not initiated, in accordance with that, instead of saying in the absence of being a Brahmin,

original: śūdratvābhāveti tadabhāvapadavyākhyānena śrutau brāhmaṇaśabdo brahmāṇanayogyatraivarṇikapara ityuktaṃ bhavati /🔽etadvākyasya yadyayamabrāhmaṇaḥ śūdraḥsyāttarhmetatsatyavacanaṃ ārjavavacanaṃ vāṅmanasayoravairūpyeṇa vacanaṃ vivaktuṃ nārhediti vipakṣe tarkoktirūpatayā /
analyzed: śūdra tva abhāva iti tad abhāva pada vyākhyānena śrutau brāhmaṇa śabdaḥ brahmāṇana yogya traivarṇika paraḥ iti uktam bhavati  etad vākyasya yadi ayam abrāhmaṇaḥ śūdraḥ syāt tarhi etat satya vacanam ārjava vacanam vāc manasayoḥ avairūpyeṇa vacanam vivaktum na arhet iti vipakṣe tarka ukti rūpatayā
translated: it is said that in the Veda, the word Brahmin refers to the three varnas who are eligible for the duties of a Brahmin, by explaining the word absence as absence of being a Shudra.🔽This statement has the form of an argument in the opposite case, as follows: If this non-Brahmin were a Shudra, then he would not be worthy of speaking these true words, straightforward words, or words of mental and verbal non-deception.

original: yo 'brāhmaṇaḥ sa evaṃ vaktuṃ nārhati satyavacanahīna iti vyatirekavyāptyuktirūpatayā vā śūdratvābhaāvanirṇāyakatvam /
analyzed: yaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ saḥ evam vaktum na arhati satya vacana hīnaḥ iti vyatireka vyāpti ukti rūpatayā vā śūdra tva abhaāva nirṇāyaka tvam
translated: Or it has the form of stating the pervasion by the negative, as follows: One who is not a Brahmin is not worthy of speaking thus, being devoid of true words. Thus, it determines the absence of being a Shudra.

analyzed: hāridrumataḥ gautamaḥ
translated: The son of Haridruma is Haridruma. Gautama.

analyzed: tasya pravṛtteḥ iti
translated: 'Because of His activity'.

original: asya na tadabhāva iti adhyāhṛtapadenānvayaḥ /🔽tathā cetthaṃ mahāvākyayojanā satyakāmasya nāhametadvedeti satyavacanena naitadabrāhmaṇo
analyzed: asya na tad abhāve iti adhyāhṛta padena anvayaḥ  tathā ca ittham mahā vākya yojanā satyakāmasya na aham etat veda iti satya vacanena na etat abrāhmaṇaḥ
translated: This is connected with the understood word 'not that absence of His'.

analyzed: vivaktum arhati iti vyatireka vyāpti jñānena bādhaka tarkeṇa ca śūdra tva abhāva nirdhāraṇe
translated: If so, the great sentence is thus connected: 'The desire of truth' (does not know this), by the statement of truth, 'a non-Brahmin is not fit to speak this', by the knowledge of the universal concomitance of the negative vyatireka, and by the argument that is contradicted, the absence of being a Shudra is determined.

analyzed: satī iva tam anumāya eva tasya satyakāmasya upanayana saṃskāre hāridrumatasya
translated: Having inferred that very 'desire of truth', he performed the initiation ceremony for him.

analyzed: gautamasya pravṛtteḥ
translated: 'Because of the activity' of Haridrumata Gautama.

original: pravṛttatvāt na śūdrasya tadabhāvaḥ saṃskāraniṣedhābhāva iti /
analyzed: pravṛtta tvāt na śūdrasya tad abhāvaḥ saṃskāra niṣedha abhāvaḥ iti
translated: Because of the activity, the absence of that, the absence of the prohibition of initiation, does not exist for a Shudra.

analyzed: caḥ hetu samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for the combination of reasons.

original: anena sūtre taditi vyastaṃ luptavibhaktikaṃ padaṃ samastaṃ ca tantreṇopāttam /
analyzed: anena sūtre tat iti vyastam lupta vibhaktikam padam samastam ca tantreṇa upāttam
translated: In this sutra, the word 'tad' (that) is used separately with the case ending omitted, and collectively in combination.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe bhinnakrameṇa
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for determination with a different sequence.

analyzed: na kevalam śūdrasya saṃskāra abhāvaḥ śruti mātrāt
translated: Not only is there an absence of initiation for a Shudra merely from the scriptures.

analyzed: kintu saṃskāra niṣedha jñāpaka liṅgāt ca iti samuccaye ca
translated: But also from the reason that indicates the prohibition of initiation, there is a combination in 'ca' (and).

analyzed: na iti asti  tad abhāve iti anuṣajyate
translated: The answer is 'no'.🔽'The absence of that' is to be supplied.

analyzed: tathā ca tasya
translated: And thus 'of Him'.

analyzed: satyakāmasya tena
translated: Of Satyakāma, 'by that'.

original: satyavacanena manovākkāyakarmaṇāṃ avaiparītyamārjavaṃ tadeva satyatvaṃ tādṛśavacanena tena jñāpitena ṛjutveneti yāvat /
analyzed: satya vacanena manaḥ vāc kāya karmaṇām a vaiparītyam ārjavam tat eva satya tvam tādṛśa vacanena tena jñāpitena ṛju tvena iti yāvat
translated: By the truth, by the statement of truth, the non-contradiction of the actions of mind, speech and body is straightforwardness. That itself is truth. By such a statement, by that, by straightforwardness, is the meaning.

original: naitadabrāhmaṇo vivaktumarhatīti vyatirekavyāptiṃ bādhakatarkaṃ copanyasya 'tadabhāvanirdhāraṇe ca' /
analyzed: na etat abrāhmaṇaḥ vivaktum arhati iti vyatireka vyāptim bādhaka tarkam ca upanyasya tad abhāva nirdhāraṇe ca
translated: Having presented the negative pervasion and the countering reasoning that a non-Brahmin is not fit to speak, 'and in the ascertainment of his absence',

original: tasya śūdratvābhāvanirṇaye satyeva tadabhāvamanumāyaiva 'samidhaṃ somyāharopa tvāneṣye' / chāṃ / / / /
analyzed: tasya śūdra tva abhāva nirṇaye sati eva tad abhāvam anumāya eva samidham somya āhara upa tvā āneṣye chām
translated: and in the ascertainment of his absence, of his being a Shudra, having inferred that absence itself, 'Bring the kindling, my dear, I will make you go', Chā.

original: iti tasya tasminnupanayanasaṃskāre tasya gautamasya pravṛtterdarśanācca na śūdrasya tadabhāvaḥ saṃskāraniṣedhābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: iti tasya tasmin upanayana saṃskāre tasya gautamasya pravṛtteḥ darśanāt ca na śūdrasya tad abhāvaḥ saṃskāra niṣedha abhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, from the seeing of Gautama's engagement in that initiation ceremony of Upanayana for him, the absence of that for a Shudra, the absence of the prohibition of initiation,

original: śūdrasya upanayananiṣedhābhāve kathamayaṃ tadabhāvanirdhāraṇe satyeva pravarteta /
analyzed: śūdrasya upanayana niṣedha abhāve katham ayam tad abhāva nirdhāraṇe sati eva pravarteta
translated: how could he engage in the ascertainment of that absence, if there were no prohibition of Upanayana for a Shudra?

original: te jñāyate niṣedho 'stīti bhāva iti sūtrārtha ukto bhavati /
analyzed: te jñāyate niṣedhaḥ sti iti bhāvaḥ iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, it is understood that there is a prohibition. This is the meaning of the sutra.

original: chāndogye hītthamākhyāyikā satyakāmo nāma ṛṣiḥ jabālākhyaṃ mātaramupetyovāca /
analyzed: chāndogye hi ittham ākhyāyikā satyakāmaḥ nāma ṛṣiḥ jabāla ākhyam mātaram upetya uvāca
translated: For in the Chandogya, the story is thus: The sage named Satyakama approached his mother named Jabala and said:

original: kimiti / ahaṃ vedādhyayanārtham ācāryamupagaccheyaṃ tatrādhyayanasyopanayanasaṃskārasāpekṣatvāt upanayanaṃ vinā te māṃ nādhyāpayeyuḥ /
analyzed: kim iti aham veda adhyayana artham ācāryam upagaccheyam tatra adhyayanasya upanayana saṃskāra sāpekṣa tvāt upanayanam vinā te mām na adhyāpayeyuḥ
translated: Why? I would approach a teacher for the study of the Vedas, and since that study requires the initiation ceremony of Upanayana, they would not teach me without the Upanayana.

original: upanayanaṃ ca gotrādyavacane na kuryuḥ ato 'haṃ kiṃ gotro 'smi tadvadeti /
analyzed: upanayanam ca gotra ādya vacane na kuryuḥ atas ham kim smi tadvat eti
translated: And they would not perform the Upanayana without knowing the Gotra etc., so I should tell them what Gotra I belong to.

original: evamuktā jabālā svaputraṃ satyakāmamabravīt he tāta tvaṃ yadgotro 'sītyetat nāhaṃ vedeti /
analyzed: evam uktā jabālā sva putram satyakāmam abravīt he tāta tvam yad gotrā si iti etat na aham veda iti
translated: Thus addressed, Jabala said to her son Satyakama, Dear, I do not know what Gotra you belong to.

analyzed: evam uktaḥ satyakāmaḥ gautamam upetya uvāca
translated: Thus addressed, Satyakama approached Gautama and said,

analyzed: kim iti he bhagavan brahmacarya artham tvām upeyam iti
translated: Why? O revered one, I come to you for the study of the Vedas.

original: evamukto gautamaḥ he somya tvaṃ kiṃgotro 'si /
analyzed: evam uktaḥ gautamaḥ he somya tvam kiṃgotraḥ si
translated: Thus addressed, Gautama said, O dear one, what Gotra do you belong to?

analyzed: tadvat eti uvāca
translated: He said, Tell me.

original: evamuktassatyakāmaḥ punargautamaṃ pratyāha nāhametadveda bho iti /
analyzed: evam uktaḥ satyakāmaḥ punar gautamam pratyāha na aham etat veda bho iti
translated: Thus addressed, Satyakama again said to Gautama, I do not know this, O revered one.

original: bho bhagavan pūjya gautama ahaṃ yadgotro 'smītyetat vedyaṃ 'na veda' /
analyzed: bho bhagavan pūjya gautama aham yad gotraḥ smi iti etat vedyam na veda
translated: O revered Gautama, I do not know what Gotra I belong to, which is to be known.

analyzed: na jānāmi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is I do not know.

original: evaṃ satyakāmasya satyavacanenārjavaṃ jñātvā punastaṃ pratyuvāca /
analyzed: evam satyakāmasya satya vacanena ārjavam jñātvā punar tam pratyuvāca
translated: Thus knowing Satyakama's sincerity through his truthful statement, he again said to him,

analyzed: na etat ityādi
translated: This is not... and so on.

analyzed: atra brāhmaṇa śabdaḥ brahmāṇana yogya traivarṇika paraḥ
translated: Here the word 'Brahmana' refers to the three varnas who are fit for the worship of Brahma.

analyzed: ārjavam brāhmaṇe sākṣāt śūdraḥ na ārjava lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: 'Honesty is directly in the Brahmana, the Shudra is characterized by dishonesty.'

analyzed: iti śruti vyākhyāna rūpāyām smṛtau brāhmaṇa pratiyogi tvena śūdrasya upādānāt
translated: In the Smriti, which is an explanation of the Shruti, the Shudra is mentioned as the counter-part of the Brahmana.

analyzed: tathā ca etat
translated: And thus 'this'

analyzed: ārjava saṃyukta vacanam a brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: The statement connected with honesty, 'the non-Brahmana,'

analyzed: traivarṇika itaraḥśūdraḥ vivaktum
translated: The Shudra who is other than the three varnas, 'should not speak,'

analyzed: sarvathā vaktum na arhati na yogyaḥ
translated: In any way, should not speak, 'is not fit.'

original: atastvamevaṃ vadan brāhmaṇa evāsi /🔽ato he somya samidhamupahara tvāmupaneṣya iti /
analyzed: atas tvam evam vadan brāhmaṇaḥ eva asi  atas he somya samidham upahara tvām upaneṣye iti
translated: Therefore, speaking thus, you are indeed a Brahmana.

analyzed: sū om
translated: Therefore, O dear one, bring the sacrificial fuel, I will initiate you.'🔽Sūtra

analyzed: śravaṇa adhyayana artha pratiṣedhāt smṛteḥ ca
translated: Because of the prohibition of listening and studying, and because of Smṛti.

analyzed: om  śravaṇe trapu jatubhyām śrotra paripūraṇam
translated: Om.🔽In listening, the ears are to be filled with lead and tin.

analyzed: adhyayane jihvā chedaḥ
translated: In studying, the tongue is to be cut off.

analyzed: artha avadhāraṇe hṛdaya vidāraṇam
translated: In understanding the meaning, the heart is to be torn apart.'

analyzed: gautama dharma
translated: The Dharma of Gautama

analyzed: iti pratiṣedhāt
translated: Thus, because of the prohibition.

analyzed: nanu aviśeṣāt iti ukta rītyā śūdrasya api viśiṣṭa buddhi ādimattvena adhikāraḥ siddhyet
translated: Now, by the reasoning stated as 'because of non-distinction,' the Shudra also would be established as qualified by having a superior intellect etc.

original: anyathā tena devatādyadhikārasiddhirapi na syāditi śaṅkāṃ pariharatsūtramupanyasya vyācaṣṭe śravaṇeti /
analyzed: anyathā tena devatā ādi adhikāra siddhiḥ api na syāt iti śaṅkām pariharat sūtram upanyasya vyācaṣṭe śravaṇa iti
translated: Otherwise, the establishment of the eligibility of gods etc. by that would also not be possible. To remove this doubt, he presents the sutra and explains it with śravaṇa.

analyzed: sūtre artha avadhāraṇe
translated: In the sutra, in the ascertainment of meaning.

analyzed: iti śruti anusārāt artha śabdaḥ tad avadhāraṇa paraḥ
translated: In accordance with the śruti, the word artha is for the ascertainment of that.

analyzed: tathā ca śravaṇe trapu jatubhyām
translated: And thus, in the śruti in hearing, with the two, tin and lac.

analyzed: iti śrutau śūdrasya veda śravaṇa adhyayana artha avadhāraṇānām pratiṣiddha tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that for a Śūdra, hearing, studying, and ascertaining the meaning of the Vedas are prohibited.

analyzed: asya na tad abhāvaḥ iti anuṣakta sādhyena anvayaḥ
translated: This is connected with the implied conclusion not that absence of that.

analyzed: adhyayana niṣedha abhāvaḥ iti tad arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is absence of prohibition of studying.

original: tathā cāniṣiddhatve sati viśiṣṭabuddhyādimattvasyaiva vedādhikāraprayojakatvenāṅgīkṛtatvāt tasya ca śūdre abhāvānna tasya devaprativandyā vedādhikāro 🔽vācya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca aniṣiddhatve sati viśiṣṭa buddhi ādimattvasya eva veda adhikāra prayojaka tvena aṅgīkṛta tvāt tasya ca śūdre abhāvāt na tasya deva prativandyāḥ veda adhikāraḥ  vācyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, when there is no prohibition, and the possession of a specific intellect etc. is accepted as the cause of eligibility for the Vedas, and that is absent in a Śūdra, therefore his eligibility for the worship of gods and the Vedas cannot be stated.

original: śūdreṇa vedaśravaṇe kṛte sati drutābhyāṃ trapujatubhyāṃ vaṅgalākṣābhyāṃ tatkarṇavivaraparipūraṇaṃ rājabhaṭaiḥ kāryamiti śrutyarthaḥ /
analyzed: śūdreṇa veda śravaṇe kṛte sati drutābhyām trapu jatubhyām vaṅga lākṣābhyām tad karṇa vivara paripūraṇam rāja bhaṭaiḥ kāryam iti śruti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning. The meaning of the śruti is that when the Vedas are heard by a Śūdra, his ear holes should be filled with molten tin and lac by the king's soldiers.

analyzed: śiṣṭaḥ sugamaḥ
translated: The rest is easy to understand.

analyzed: na agniḥ na yajñaḥ śūdrasya tathā eva adhyayanam kutas
translated: For a Shudra there is no fire, no sacrifice, and how can there be study?

analyzed: kevalā eva tu śuśrūṣā tri varṇānām vidhīyate
translated: Only service is prescribed for the three varnas.

analyzed: iti smṛteḥ ca
translated: And because of this Smriti.

original: śrutau śūdreṇa śravaṇe kṛte ityanuktervarṇabāhyaviṣayeyaṃ śrutiḥ kiṃ na syādityāśaṅkānivṛtyarthaṃ sūtre smṛteścetyuktaṃ /
analyzed: śrutau śūdreṇa śravaṇe kṛte iti anukteḥ varṇa bāhya viṣayā iyam śrutiḥ kim na syāt iti āśaṅkā nivṛti artham sūtre smṛteḥ ca iti uktam
translated: Since it is not stated in the Shruti that the Shudra should listen, could this Shruti not refer to one outside the varnas? To remove this doubt, the word Smriti is used in the sutra.

analyzed: tām smṛtim udāharati na iti
translated: He cites that Smriti with the word na (no).

analyzed: yathā śūdrasya
translated: Just as for a Shudra.

original: śūdreṇa nāgnissavathā ādhātavyaḥ pañcavidho yajño 'pi nānuṣṭheyaḥ /
analyzed: śūdreṇa na agniḥ savathā ādhātavyaḥ pañcavidhaḥ yajñaḥ na anuṣṭheyaḥ
translated: A Shudra should not kindle the five kinds of sacrificial fires, nor should he perform the five kinds of sacrifices.

analyzed: tathā adhyayanam kutas bhavet na kutas pi
translated: Similarly, how can there be study? Not from anywhere.

original: tarhi tenānuṣṭheyaṃ paralokasādhanaṃ kimiti pṛcchati tu kintviti /
analyzed: tarhi tena anuṣṭheyam para loka sādhanam kim iti pṛcchati tu kintu iti
translated: Then what should he do to attain the next world? He asks this with the word tu (but).

analyzed: uttaram āha kevalā eva iti
translated: He answers with the word kevala (only).

analyzed: bhṛti rahitā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is without wages.

analyzed: trayaḥ ca te varṇāḥ ca tri varṇāḥ
translated: And those three are the varnas, so they are the three varnas.

analyzed: teṣām brahma kṣatriya vaiśyānām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is of the Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas.

analyzed: śuśrūṣā paricaryā eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Service - the connection is only with attendance.

analyzed: vidhīyate
translated: Is prescribed.

analyzed: kārya tvena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is to be done.

original: iti smṛterityasya śūdrasyaivādhyayananiṣedhāvagamāt na tadabhāva ityadhyāhṛtenānvayaḥ /
analyzed: iti smṛteḥ iti asya śūdrasya eva adhyayana niṣedha avagamāt na tad abhāve iti adhyāhṛtena anvayaḥ
translated: Thus, the meaning is that because of this Smṛti text, it is understood that there is a prohibition of study for the Śūdra only, not its absence. The word absence is to be supplied.

original: tathā ca spaṣṭasmṛtibalāt śruterapi śūdraviṣayatvameveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca spaṣṭa smṛti balāt śruteḥ api śūdra viṣaya tvam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, by the power of the clear Smṛti text, even the Vedic text refers to the Śūdra only. This is the idea.

analyzed: vidura ādīnām tu utpanna jñāna tvāt kaścid viśeṣaḥ
translated: But Vidura and others have a certain distinction, because they have attained knowledge.

analyzed: iti apaśūdrā adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on non-Śūdras.

original: nanu śūdrasya vedārthāvadhāraṇāderniṣiddhatve kathaṃ vidurādīnāṃ vaidikārthāvadhāraṇamasti /
analyzed: nanu śūdrasya veda artha avadhāraṇa ādeḥ niṣiddha tve katham vidura ādīnām vaidika artha avadhāraṇam asti
translated: If the determination of the meaning of the Veda is prohibited for the Śūdra, how is it that Vidura and others have the determination of the Vedic meaning?

original: evaṃ saṃskārarahitānāṃ vedānadhikāre kathaṃ kṣatriyaḥ saṃskārarahitaḥ karṇaḥ nikhilāḥ śrutīradhijagau /
analyzed: evam saṃskāra rahitānām veda anadhikāre katham kṣatriyaḥ saṃskāra rahitaḥ karṇaḥ nikhilāḥ śrutīḥ adhijagau
translated: Similarly, if those devoid of consecration are not entitled to the Vedas, how is it that the Kṣatriya Karṇa, devoid of consecration, recited all the Vedas?

analyzed: na ca vācyam asau apavāda viṣayaḥ iti
translated: And it cannot be said that he is the subject of an exception.

analyzed: iti śabda anantaram suṣuptī iti sautra padam saṃyojyam

analyzed: vyapadeśāt iti buddhyā vivicya pūrvasmāt anuṣaktam padam

original: asaṅga ityapi hetusūcanāya sūtre adhyāhṛtaṃ padam /

analyzed: tathātve suṣupti śabdaḥ kartari ktin antaḥ

original: utkrāntiśabdaḥ dehādutkrāmayitṛparaḥ tathā cetthaṃ yojanā svapnādidraṣṭṛtvaṃ tasya paramātmana eva bhavet na jīvasya /

analyzed: kutas yatas sa avasaṅgaḥ śrutaḥ

original: na ca svapnādidraṣṭuḥ asaṅgatvaśravaṇe 'pi kuto 'yaṃ viṣṇuriti vācyam /

analyzed: tathā ca prājñena

analyzed: sarvajñena paramātmanā sampariṣvaktaḥ

analyzed: tathā brāhmaṇa ākhya viṣayaḥ pi sūcitaḥ

original: yadvā devānāmiti vākyaṃ devatādhikaraṇapratipādyānuvādaparatvenāpi vyākhyāya tenāsyākṣepikī saṅgatiruktā draṣṭavyā /

analyzed: tathā hi tad upari
translated: For thus,

original: iti sūtreṇa devānāṃ viriñcādyamarāṇāṃ vidyākarmaṇossakāśāt sādhyā yā nityapadaprāptiruktā / sā na yuktā /

translated: by the sūtra above that (Brahma-Sūtra 1.1.2), the attainment of the eternal state of the gods, Viriñca (Brahmā) and the other immortals, from knowledge and action, which is stated, is not proper.

analyzed: śrutau brahmaṇā vedena aṇyate vagamyate iti vyutpattiḥ
translated: In the Vedic text, the derivation is: is known by Brahman, by the Veda.

original: tathā ca brāhmaṇasya viṣṇoreṣaḥ pūrvoktamahimā nityaḥ /

translated: And thus, this greatness of Vishnu, the Brahman, mentioned earlier, is eternal.

original: kuto / yato 'yaṃ 'na karmaṇā vardhate no kanīyān' / bṛ / / / /

translated: Why? Because he does not increase by action, nor does he decrease.

analyzed: śubha karmaṇā tad phalena sukhena na vardhate

translated: He does not decrease by bad action and its fruit, sorrow. This is the meaning of the Vedic text.

analyzed: sa yuktikam pūrvapakṣayati saḥ iti
